p: The use of ethanol as an excipient carries potential hazards and adverse effects, which are already observed at a dose of 100 mg/dL. These effects include hypoglycaemia, acidosis and hydro-electrolytic alterations. Very high intake can lead to stupor, coma, respiratory depression and cardiovascular collapse. Hypoglycaemic seizures may also occur in children [ 29, 31]. For all these side effects, any alcohol should be avoided in paediatric forms. However, it is still used in many liquid preparations, because it is the only solvent that allows the solubilization of certain active substances [ 29].
